results.title: Our Prime Minister
results.creator_credit: Ezra Mir and Films Division, Government of India
results.brief_description: A compilation of newsreel footage on the life of Nehru, late Prime Minister of India, who was known all over the world as a symbol of the blending of old and new India. Under his guidance, the country was transformed, and although holding great power he was always accessible to all people. He visited all parts of India and many countries of the world; in turn Delhi became a meeting place for world leaders due to Nehru’s dynamic foreign policy and his belief in the goal of a peaceful world. A portrait of a man of charm, simple tastes and fine intellect who led India in times of strife and in a manner which earned the love and respect of millions.

results.title: Our potential allies
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description:
‘Our Potential Allies’ is an intuitive and ironic critique of Eurocentric belief-systems founded upon the dichotomy of self (the West) and the Other. Callas appears on the left monitor in black and white facial paint – the so-called ‘mask of primitivism’ – while compressed news imagery appears upon the right. Facial gestures are enacted by the artist seemingly in response to the voice-over (instructions issued by General Douglas MacArthur to American soldiers fighting in Papua New Guinea during the Second World War) or to imagery on the right monitor. Questions of intent – a constant theme throughout Callas’ career – are thus raised in relation to the creation of apparently random meaning.
Notes by Rachel Kent, reprinted courtesy of the author and d/Lux Media Arts.

results.title: Our pandas
results.creator_credit: TV Ed Productions and Stephen Skok
results.brief_description: A look at the pandas Fei Fei and Xiao Xiao during their visit to their visit to the Melbourne Zoo in 1988. The program includes interviews with their Australian and Chinese keepers.

results.title: Our original inhabitants
results.creator_credit: M. Bhavnani, Documentary Films of India and Jagat Murari
results.brief_description: The original inhabitants of India number some 25 million and belong to 172 groups spread over the sub-continent. The culture, dress, dance and music of the Gonds, Santhals, Todas, Bhils and the Nagas are amongst the tribes mentioned.
results.creator_credit_for_label: M. Bhavnani, Documentary Films of India and Jagat Murari

results.title: Our neighbour: Australia
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Agha Bashir Ahmad and Rashid Khan
results.brief_description: A general survey of Australia, its resources and its work under the Colombo Plan, as seen through the eyes of a student from South-East Asia. This film is the work of two Pakistan students, who came to Australia under the Colombo Plan to study the profession of film-making at the studios of the Films Division of the Department of the Interior.

results.title: Our neighbour Nepal
results.brief_description: Nepal, homeland of the Gurkha soldiers. Its people and rulers, customs, homes, palaces, religious shrines and temples; the King and government; the Ranas, a ruling clique; the disturbances of 1950 and the King’s flight to India; his return and the subsequent visit of Nehru to Katmandu.

results.title: Our native shore
results.creator_credit: Andrew Rice, Esso Film Unit, British Information Services and Ronald Stark
results.brief_description: Shows the people whose lives and work are centred directly on the coastal areas of the British Isles and to whom the sea and ships are a part of their lives. Fisherman, coast guard, merchant seaman, life boat man, harbourmaster, shipwright, yachtsman, lighthouse keeper and a score of others move against a background rich in natural beauty and historical associations.

results.title: Our national heritage: the living pattern
results.creator_credit: Ralph Keene, Pilot Films, National Benzole and John Taylor
results.brief_description: Britain’s wildlife is the theme of this film. It shows most of the principal surviving wild animals in Britain, then the work of the Nature Conservancy in preserving them in nature reserves and elsewhere, and in carrying out ecological research.

results.title: Our Mutual friend
results.creator_credit: Catherine Wearing, BBC-TV and Julian Farino
results.brief_description: Based on Charles Dickens last completed novel, this production paints a sweeping picture of London in the 19th century. With its themes of class war, sexual jealousy and overwhelming passion, it is a tale that is as relevant today as when Dickens first penned it.
